Easy.question: What river was crucial to the development of Ancient Egyptian civilization?
Easy.fun_fact: The Nile's annual flooding created fertile soil that allowed Egyptian agriculture to flourish.

Easy.question: Who was the boy king of Egypt whose intact tomb was discovered in 1922?
Easy.fun_fact: Tutankhamun became pharaoh at age 9 and died around age 18.

Easy.question: What writing system did ancient Egyptians use?
Easy.fun_fact: Hieroglyphics were deciphered using the Rosetta Stone which contained the same text in three scripts.

Easy.question: What were the massive tombs built for pharaohs called?
Easy.fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only surviving wonder of the ancient world.

Easy.question: Which female pharaoh dressed as a man to strengthen her claim to the throne?
Easy.fun_fact: Hatshepsut was one of Egypt's most successful rulers, reigning for about 22 years.

Easy.question: What plant grew along the Nile and was used to make paper?
Easy.fun_fact: The word 'paper' comes from 'papyrus'.

Easy.question: Who was the sun god worshipped by ancient Egyptians?
Easy.fun_fact: Ra was believed to travel across the sky by day and through the underworld by night.

Easy.question: What was the process of preserving dead bodies called in ancient Egypt?
Easy.fun_fact: The process took about 70 days and involved removing internal organs except the heart.

Easy.question: Which famous queen had relationships with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony?
Easy.fun_fact: Cleopatra was actually Greek, descended from one of Alexander the Great's generals.

Easy.question: What animal was considered sacred in ancient Egypt?
Easy.fun_fact: Killing a cat, even accidentally, was punishable by death in ancient Egypt.

Medium.question: What was the capital of Egypt during most of the Old Kingdom period?
Medium.fun_fact: Memphis was founded around 3100 BCE and was the capital for over 800 years.

Medium.question: Which pharaoh attempted to establish monotheism by worshipping only Aten?
Medium.fun_fact: This religious revolution was reversed soon after Akhenaten's death.

Medium.question: What was the name of the script developed as a simplified form of hieroglyphics for everyday use?
Medium.fun_fact: Hieratic script was used for about 2,000 years before being replaced by Demotic.

Medium.question: Which battle in 1274 BCE between Egypt and the Hittites is one of the earliest recorded battles?
Medium.fun_fact: Both sides claimed victory in this battle, which may have involved 5,000-6,000 chariots.

Medium.question: What was the name of the last native Egyptian dynasty before Persian conquest?
Medium.fun_fact: This dynasty ruled from 380 BCE to 343 BCE before being overthrown by the Persians.

Medium.question: Which famous female pharaoh was the chief wife of Akhenaten?
Medium.fun_fact: Nefertiti may have ruled as co-regent and perhaps independently after Akhenaten's death.

Medium.question: What was the name of the calendar developed by ancient Egyptians?
Medium.fun_fact: The Egyptian solar calendar had 365 days divided into 12 months of 30 days plus 5 extra days.

Medium.question: Which Nubian dynasty ruled Egypt during the 25th Dynasty?
Medium.fun_fact: The Kushite pharaohs promoted a return to Egyptian traditions after the Third Intermediate Period.

Medium.question: What was the name of the administrative region in ancient Egypt?
Medium.fun_fact: There were originally 42 nomes - 22 in Upper Egypt and 20 in Lower Egypt.

Medium.question: Which famous stone helped decipher Egyptian hieroglyphs?
Medium.fun_fact: The Rosetta Stone contains the same text in Greek, Demotic, and Hieroglyphic scripts.

Hard.question: Which pharaoh of the 19th Dynasty is known for his extensive building programs and long reign?
Hard.fun_fact: Ramses II ruled for 66 years and may have fathered over 100 children.

Hard.question: What was the name of the capital established by Akhenaten for his new religion?
Hard.fun_fact: The city was abandoned shortly after Akhenaten's death and is now known as Amarna.

Hard.question: Which queen of Egypt was the mother of Akhenaten and possibly ruled as pharaoh?
Hard.fun_fact: Tiye was of Nubian descent and wielded considerable influence during her son's reign.

Hard.question: What was the name of the intermediate period between the Old and Middle Kingdoms?
Hard.fun_fact: This was a time of political fragmentation and instability lasting about 125 years.

Hard.question: Which Nubian kingdom conquered Egypt in the 8th century BCE?
Hard.fun_fact: The Kushite rulers of Egypt's 25th Dynasty promoted themselves as restorers of Egyptian tradition.

Hard.question: What was the name of the female pharaoh who ruled during the 12th Dynasty?
Hard.fun_fact: Sobekneferu was the first confirmed female pharaoh of Egypt, ruling for about 4 years.

Hard.question: Which Hyksos king introduced the horse and chariot to Egypt?
Hard.fun_fact: The Hyksos ruled during the Second Intermediate Period and were eventually expelled by Ahmose I.

Hard.question: What was the name of the vizier who designed Djoser's Step Pyramid?
Hard.fun_fact: Imhotep was later deified as a god of medicine and healing.

Hard.question: Which pharaoh's intact tomb was discovered by Howard Carter in 1922?
Hard.fun_fact: The tomb contained over 5,000 artifacts and took nearly 10 years to catalog.

Hard.question: What was the name of the last active hieroglyphic inscription, dated to 394 CE?
Hard.fun_fact: This marks the end of nearly 3,500 years of Egyptian hieroglyphic writing.

Easy.question: Who was the first emperor of Rome?
Easy.fun_fact: Augustus was originally named Octavian and was Julius Caesar's adopted heir.

Easy.question: What was the common language of the Roman Empire?
Easy.fun_fact: Latin evolved into the Romance languages: Italian, French, Spanish, Portuguese, and Romanian.

Easy.question: Where did gladiators fight in Rome?
Easy.fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold 50,000-80,000 spectators and hosted mock sea battles.

Easy.question: Which volcano destroyed Pompeii in 79 CE?
Easy.fun_fact: Pompeii was preserved under volcanic ash, providing remarkable insights into Roman life.

Easy.question: What were Roman foot soldiers called?
Easy.fun_fact: Roman soldiers carried about 60 pounds of equipment on long marches.

Easy.question: Which emperor built a wall in northern Britain?
Easy.fun_fact: Hadrian's Wall stretched 73 miles across northern England and took 6 years to build.

Easy.question: What was the center of political life in Rome?
Easy.fun_fact: The Forum was the site of triumphal processions, elections, and public speeches.

Easy.question: Who was the Carthaginian general who crossed the Alps with elephants?
Easy.fun_fact: Hannibal lost most of his elephants during the crossing of the Alps.

Easy.question: What was the period of peace and prosperity in the Roman Empire called?
Easy.fun_fact: The Pax Romana lasted approximately 200 years from 27 BCE to 180 CE.

Easy.question: Which emperor converted to Christianity?
Easy.fun_fact: Constantine issued the Edict of Milan in 313 CE, legalizing Christianity in the empire.

Medium.question: What was the name of the series of wars between Rome and Carthage?
Medium.fun_fact: There were three Punic Wars spanning over a century (264-146 BCE).

Medium.question: Which emperor divided the empire into eastern and western halves?
Medium.fun_fact: Diocletian established the Tetrarchy system with two senior and two junior emperors.

Medium.question: What was the name of Rome's first law code?
Medium.fun_fact: The Twelve Tables were inscribed on bronze tablets and displayed in the Forum around 450 BCE.

Medium.question: Which emperor famously 'fiddled while Rome burned'?
Medium.fun_fact: The story is likely a myth as the fiddle hadn't been invented yet, and Nero was actually away from Rome when the fire started.

Medium.question: What was the name of the slave who led a major rebellion against Rome?
Medium.fun_fact: Spartacus's rebellion lasted two years (73-71 BCE) before being crushed by Crassus.

Medium.question: Which Roman general was defeated by Hannibal at Cannae?
Medium.fun_fact: The Battle of Cannae (216 BCE) is considered one of the worst defeats in Roman history, with possibly 50,000 Romans killed.

Medium.question: What was the name of the eastern Roman Empire that survived after the west fell?
Medium.fun_fact: The Byzantine Empire lasted nearly 1,000 years after the fall of Rome until 1453.

Medium.question: Which emperor made Christianity the official religion of the Roman Empire?
Medium.fun_fact: Theodosius issued the Edict of Thessalonica in 380 CE, making Nicene Christianity the state religion.

Medium.question: What was the name of the professional Roman army units?
Medium.fun_fact: A full Roman legion consisted of about 5,000 heavily armed infantry soldiers.

Medium.question: Which famous Roman leader was assassinated on the Ides of March?
Medium.fun_fact: Caesar was stabbed 23 times by a group of senators led by Brutus and Cassius in 44 BCE.

Hard.question: Which emperor built the massive bath complex that still stands in Rome today?
Hard.fun_fact: The Baths of Caracalla could accommodate 1,600 bathers and included libraries and exercise areas.

Hard.question: What was the name of the crisis in the 3rd century marked by frequent imperial turnover?
Hard.fun_fact: During this 50-year period, Rome had over 20 emperors, most reigning for just a few years.

Hard.question: Which Roman emperor famously made his horse a consul?
Hard.fun_fact: The story may be apocryphal, but it illustrates Caligula's erratic and tyrannical behavior.

Hard.question: What was the name of the last western Roman emperor?
Hard.fun_fact: His deposition in 476 CE by Odoacer is traditionally marked as the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

Hard.question: Which Roman general defeated Mark Antony and Cleopatra at Actium?
Hard.fun_fact: This naval battle in 31 BCE marked the end of the Roman Republic and beginning of the Empire.

Hard.question: What was the name of the legal code commissioned by Justinian I?
Hard.fun_fact: This code formed the basis of civil law in many modern European countries.

Hard.question: Which Germanic leader sacked Rome in 410 CE?
Hard.fun_fact: This was the first time Rome had been sacked in 800 years, shocking the Roman world.

Hard.question: What was the name of the Roman province where Jesus was born?
Hard.fun_fact: Judea was a client kingdom of Rome during Jesus's lifetime before becoming a full province in 6 CE.

Hard.question: Which emperor built a massive wall in northern Britain?
Hard.fun_fact: Hadrian's Wall marked the northern limit of Roman Britain and took about 6 years to build.

Hard.question: What was the name of the eastern capital founded by Constantine?
Hard.fun_fact: Constantinople (modern Istanbul) became the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire for over 1,000 years.

Easy.question: Which countries were the main Axis powers in WWII?
Easy.fun_fact: The Axis powers were formally linked by the Tripartite Pact signed in September 1940.

Easy.question: When did WWII begin with Germany's invasion of Poland?
Easy.fun_fact: Britain and France declared war on Germany two days after the invasion, on September 3, 1939.

Easy.question: Which event caused the United States to enter WWII?
Easy.fun_fact: The attack on December 7, 1941 destroyed or damaged 19 U.S. ships and 300 aircraft.

Easy.question: Who was the leader of Nazi Germany during WWII?
Easy.fun_fact: Hitler committed suicide in his Berlin bunker on April 30, 1945 as Soviet forces closed in.

Easy.question: What was the Holocaust?
Easy.fun_fact: Approximately 6 million Jews were murdered in the Holocaust along with millions of others.

Easy.question: Where were atomic bombs dropped in 1945?
Easy.fun_fact: The bomb on Hiroshima killed about 140,000 people; Nagasaki about 74,000.

Easy.question: What was D-Day?
Easy.fun_fact: On June 6, 1944, over 156,000 Allied troops landed on five beaches in Normandy, France.

Easy.question: Which country was not occupied by Germany during WWII?
Easy.fun_fact: Though heavily bombed during the Blitz, Britain successfully resisted German invasion.

Easy.question: Who was the British Prime Minister during most of WWII?
Easy.fun_fact: Churchill's speeches were instrumental in boosting British morale during the war.

Easy.question: What was the Manhattan Project?
Easy.fun_fact: The project employed over 130,000 people and cost nearly $2 billion (about $23 billion today).

Medium.question: Which battle was the turning point on the Eastern Front?
Medium.fun_fact: This brutal battle resulted in nearly 2 million casualties and marked the beginning of Germany's retreat from Russia.

Medium.question: What was the 'Final Solution'?
Medium.fun_fact: The Wannsee Conference in January 1942 coordinated the implementation of the Final Solution.

Medium.question: Which country switched from Axis to Allies during the war?
Medium.fun_fact: Italy surrendered in 1943 after Mussolini was overthrown, then declared war on Germany.

Medium.question: What was the largest concentration camp?
Medium.fun_fact: Approximately 1.1 million people were killed at Auschwitz-Birkenau, about 90% of them Jews.

Medium.question: Which battle was the largest tank battle in history?
Medium.fun_fact: At Kursk in 1943, about 6,000 tanks, 4,000 aircraft and 2 million troops clashed.

Medium.question: What was the code name for Nazi Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union?
Medium.fun_fact: Launched in June 1941, it was the largest military operation in history with over 4 million Axis troops.

Medium.question: Which conference decided Germany's post-war division?
Medium.fun_fact: At Yalta in February 1945, Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin planned the post-war world.

Medium.question: What was the name of the German air force?
Medium.fun_fact: The Luftwaffe conducted the Blitz against Britain but lost the Battle of Britain in 1940.

Medium.question: Which country suffered the highest military casualties in WWII?
Medium.fun_fact: The USSR lost an estimated 10-11 million soldiers and 15-20 million civilians.

Medium.question: What was the 'Night of Broken Glass' in Nazi Germany?
Medium.fun_fact: Kristallnacht in November 1938 saw the destruction of Jewish businesses and synagogues across Germany.

Hard.question: Which German field marshal was known as the 'Desert Fox'?
Hard.fun_fact: Rommel commanded German forces in North Africa and was implicated in the plot to kill Hitler.

Hard.question: What was the code name for the Allied invasion of North Africa?
Hard.fun_fact: This November 1942 operation marked the first major Allied offensive in the European theater.

Hard.question: Which battle marked the end of Japanese expansion in the Pacific?
Hard.fun_fact: At Midway in June 1942, the US sank four Japanese carriers, turning the tide in the Pacific.

Hard.question: What was the name of the Japanese suicide pilots?
Hard.fun_fact: Kamikaze means 'divine wind' and refers to a typhoon that destroyed a Mongol invasion fleet in 1281.

Hard.question: Which country was divided into occupation zones after WWII?
Hard.fun_fact: Germany was divided into American, British, French and Soviet zones, leading to East and West Germany.

Hard.question: What was the name of the US program to supply allies before entering the war?
Hard.fun_fact: The US sent $50 billion (about $650 billion today) in supplies to allies under Lend-Lease.

Hard.question: Which battle was Hitler's last major offensive in the west?
Hard.fun_fact: The December 1944 offensive created a 'bulge' in Allied lines but ultimately failed.

Hard.question: What was the name of the Nazi's main anti-aircraft gun?
Hard.fun_fact: The versatile 88mm gun was used against aircraft, tanks and fortifications.

Hard.question: Which country developed the first operational jet fighter?
Hard.fun_fact: The Messerschmitt Me 262 entered service in 1944 but came too late to affect the war's outcome.

Hard.question: What was the code name for the Allied deception plan before D-Day?
Hard.fun_fact: This elaborate deception made Germans believe the invasion would come at Calais rather than Normandy.

Easy.question: In what year did the American Revolution begin?
Easy.fun_fact: The first shots were fired at Lexington and Concord in April 1775.

Easy.question: Who was the main author of the Declaration of Independence?
Easy.fun_fact: Jefferson wrote the first draft in just a few days in June 1776.

Easy.question: Which country helped the American colonies win independence?
Easy.fun_fact: French aid was crucial, especially at the decisive Battle of Yorktown in 1781.

Easy.question: What was the last major battle of the American Revolution?
Easy.fun_fact: The British surrender at Yorktown in October 1781 effectively ended the war.

Easy.question: Who was the commander of the Continental Army?
Easy.fun_fact: Washington never won a major battle until Yorktown but kept the army together.

Easy.question: What famous event involved colonists dumping tea into Boston Harbor?
Easy.fun_fact: In December 1773, colonists dumped 342 chests of British tea to protest taxes.

Easy.question: Which document officially ended the American Revolution?
Easy.fun_fact: The 1783 treaty recognized American independence and set new borders.

Easy.question: What were American colonists who remained loyal to Britain called?
Easy.fun_fact: About 15-20% of colonists were Loyalists, many of whom fled to Canada after the war.

Easy.question: Which battle is known as the 'turning point' of the Revolution?
Easy.fun_fact: The American victory at Saratoga in 1777 convinced France to join the war.

Easy.question: What was the first constitution of the United States?
Easy.fun_fact: The Articles created a weak central government and were replaced by the Constitution in 1789.

Medium.question: Which European military officer helped train Washington's army?
Medium.fun_fact: Von Steuben wrote the Revolutionary War Drill Manual that standardized Continental Army training.

Medium.question: What was the name of the colonial militia ready to fight at a minute's notice?
Medium.fun_fact: The Minutemen were among the first to fight at Lexington and Concord.

Medium.question: Which patriot famously said 'Give me liberty or give me death'?
Medium.fun_fact: Henry gave this speech in 1775 to urge Virginia to raise a militia against Britain.

Medium.question: What winter encampment saw terrible suffering for Washington's army?
Medium.fun_fact: During the winter of 1777-78, about 2,500 soldiers died from disease and exposure at Valley Forge.

Medium.question: Which battle was fought on Christmas night 1776?
Medium.fun_fact: Washington's surprise attack across the Delaware River captured nearly 1,000 Hessian soldiers.

Medium.question: Who was the king of England during the American Revolution?
Medium.fun_fact: George III ruled for 60 years (1760-1820) and struggled with mental illness later in life.

Medium.question: Which pamphlet by Thomas Paine inspired colonists to seek independence?
Medium.fun_fact: Published in 1776, it sold over 500,000 copies and was widely read aloud in taverns.

Medium.question: What was the name of the American traitor who switched to the British side?
Medium.fun_fact: Arnold was a brilliant general who became bitter and plotted to surrender West Point to the British.

Medium.question: Which European nation declared war on Britain in 1779, aiding the Americans?
Medium.fun_fact: Spain's involvement forced Britain to fight on multiple fronts, stretching its resources.

Medium.question: What was the name of the treaty that ended the American Revolution?
Medium.fun_fact: Signed in 1783, it granted the U.S. all land east of the Mississippi River except Florida.

Hard.question: Which battle saw the British surrender an entire army of over 7,000 men?
Hard.fun_fact: General Burgoyne's surrender at Saratoga in 1777 was a major turning point in the war.

Hard.question: What was the name of the German mercenaries hired by the British?
Hard.fun_fact: About 30,000 German troops fought for Britain, many from the Hesse region.

Hard.question: Which naval commander famously said 'I have not yet begun to fight'?
Hard.fun_fact: Jones uttered these words during a fierce naval battle against the British ship Serapis in 1779.

Hard.question: What was the name of Washington's spy network?
Hard.fun_fact: This secret group operated in British-occupied New York and provided crucial intelligence.

Hard.question: Which state was the first to declare independence from Britain?
Hard.fun_fact: Rhode Island declared independence on May 4, 1776, two months before the Continental Congress.

Hard.question: What was the name of the British strategy to divide the colonies along the Hudson River?
Hard.fun_fact: This plan aimed to isolate New England but failed with Burgoyne's surrender at Saratoga.

Hard.question: Which battle is known as the 'shot heard round the world'?
Hard.fun_fact: This phrase from Emerson's poem refers to the opening shots of the Revolution in April 1775.

Hard.question: What was the name of the colonial protest group that opposed British taxes?
Hard.fun_fact: This secret organization led protests like the Boston Tea Party and tarred and feathered tax collectors.

Hard.question: Which British general surrendered at Yorktown?
Hard.fun_fact: Cornwallis claimed to be ill and sent his second-in-command to formally surrender.

Hard.question: What was the name of the colonial currency that became worthless during the war?
Hard.fun_fact: The phrase 'not worth a Continental' referred to the hyperinflation of this currency.

Easy.question: In which country did the Renaissance begin?
Easy.fun_fact: The Renaissance began in Florence, Italy in the 14th century before spreading across Europe.

Easy.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
Easy.fun_fact: Da Vinci worked on the Mona Lisa for about 16 years and carried it with him until his death.

Easy.question: What does 'Renaissance' mean in French?
Easy.fun_fact: The term refers to the revival of classical art, literature and learning after the Middle Ages.

Easy.question: Who invented the printing press with movable type?
Easy.fun_fact: Gutenberg's Bible (1455) was the first major book printed with movable type in Europe.

Easy.question: Which family ruled Florence and were great patrons of the arts?
Easy.fun_fact: The Medici family produced four popes and two queens of France while supporting artists like Michelangelo.

Easy.question: Who sculpted the statue of David?
Easy.fun_fact: Michelangelo carved David from a single block of marble that other sculptors had rejected as flawed.

Easy.question: Which Renaissance figure was known as the 'Renaissance Man'?
Easy.fun_fact: Da Vinci excelled in art, science, engineering, anatomy and many other fields.

Easy.question: What was the dominant art style before the Renaissance?
Easy.fun_fact: Renaissance artists rejected Gothic style in favor of classical Greek and Roman influences.

Easy.question: Which English playwright flourished during the Renaissance?
Easy.fun_fact: Shakespeare wrote 37 plays and 154 sonnets during the English Renaissance.

Easy.question: What technique gives paintings depth and perspective?
Easy.fun_fact: Developed by Brunelleschi, this mathematical system made paintings appear three-dimensional.

Medium.question: Who wrote 'The Prince,' a guide to political power?
Medium.fun_fact: Machiavelli wrote this controversial work while exiled from Florentine politics.

Medium.question: Which Renaissance artist painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling?
Medium.fun_fact: Michelangelo painted the ceiling lying on his back on scaffolding, taking about four years.

Medium.question: What was the name of the intellectual movement that emphasized human potential?
Medium.fun_fact: Humanists studied classical texts to improve human society rather than focusing solely on religion.

Medium.question: Which Renaissance scientist proposed the heliocentric model of the solar system?
Medium.fun_fact: Copernicus's theory that Earth revolved around the sun contradicted Church doctrine.

Medium.question: Who wrote 'Utopia' about an ideal society?
Medium.fun_fact: More coined the word 'utopia' from Greek words meaning 'no place' and 'good place'.

Medium.question: Which artist is known for his 'School of Athens' fresco?
Medium.fun_fact: The painting depicts famous Greek philosophers with faces of Renaissance artists like Leonardo as Plato.

Medium.question: What was the name of Leonardo da Vinci's famous notebook?
Medium.fun_fact: Bill Gates bought the Codex Leicester in 1994 for $30.8 million.

Medium.question: Which Renaissance pope was known for his patronage of the arts?
Medium.fun_fact: Nicknamed the 'Warrior Pope,' Julius II commissioned Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling.

Medium.question: What technique uses light and shadow to create depth in paintings?
Medium.fun_fact: Leonardo da Vinci and Caravaggio were masters of this dramatic lighting technique.

Medium.question: Which family ruled Milan during the Renaissance?
Medium.fun_fact: Ludovico Sforza commissioned Leonardo's 'Last Supper' and ruled Milan during its golden age.

Hard.question: Who designed the dome of Florence Cathedral?
Hard.fun_fact: The dome was the largest in the world when built and required innovative engineering techniques.

Hard.question: Which Renaissance artist invented the one-point perspective system?
Hard.fun_fact: Brunelleschi demonstrated perspective mathematically by painting the Florence Baptistery on a mirror.

Hard.question: What was the name of the Venetian painting technique using layers of translucent paint?
Hard.fun_fact: Titian and other Venetian artists used this method to create luminous color effects.

Hard.question: Which Renaissance artist was known for his bronze 'David'?
Hard.fun_fact: Donatello's David was the first free-standing nude sculpture since antiquity.

Hard.question: What was the name of the intellectual circle surrounding Lorenzo de' Medici?
Hard.fun_fact: This group studied Plato's works and influenced Renaissance humanist philosophy.

Hard.question: Which Renaissance pope was Rodrigo Borgia?
Hard.fun_fact: The most notorious Renaissance pope, Alexander VI had several children including Cesare and Lucrezia Borgia.

Hard.question: What was the name of the famous Renaissance art competition for Florence Baptistery doors?
Hard.fun_fact: Ghiberti won over Brunelleschi in this 1401 competition, creating magnificent bronze doors.

Hard.question: Which Renaissance artist pioneered the use of oil paint in Italy?
Hard.fun_fact: Messina learned oil painting techniques from Flemish artists and introduced them to Venice.

Hard.question: What was the name of the Venetian school of painting known for color and light?
Hard.fun_fact: Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese led this style that contrasted with Florentine emphasis on drawing.

Hard.question: Which Renaissance architect wrote 'On the Art of Building'?
Hard.fun_fact: Alberti's treatise was the first architectural theory book of the Renaissance.
